content.rendered:
Brain Trauma Education

This covers the content on how concussions, drugs, and alcohol are connected to brain trauma. For more details, click here.

Concussion Defined

Sport Australia defines concussion as a brain injury caused by a knock to the head or other parts of  the body where the head bears the impact of the force. A fall can also result in a concussion.  Concussion involves temporary, neurological impairment. The symptoms may evolve over the hours  or days following the injury. While a doctor should assess all concussions, most will resolve without  the need for specific treatment. Rest, followed by gradual return to activity is the main treatment.  

Concussion can lead to long-term health problems, and repeated concussion increases this risk.  

Signs and Symptoms

How To Recognise It

Recognising concussion can be difficult. Delaying treatment can be fatal. There are several possible  symptoms and signs, but they can be hard to recognise. You should suspect a concussion when an injury results in a knock to the head or body that transmits a force to the head. A hard knock is not required. 

The Sport Concussion Assessment Tool (‘SCAT5’) can assist with this process.

Signs and Symptoms

The signs of concussion vary and may be difficult to detect. For example, individuals may:  

  • seem normal apart from appearing vacant, dazed or stunned  
  • be unable to recall who the opponent is, where they are or what day it is, ask about what happened – amnesia is common  
  • have difficulty concentrating and answering specific questions.  

Loss of consciousness, seizure or balance difficulties are clear signs of a significant injury. Urgent medical support is critical in these circumstances.  

Symptoms of concussion can be very subtle and may present as nothing more than individuals  reporting that they do not ‘feel right’. Patients often report these symptoms:  

  • visual disturbance  
  • feeling ‘foggy’, lethargic or slow  
  • having sensitivity to light or noise  
  • feeling dizzy or nauseous  
  • headache.  

For examples of signs and symptoms visit the Concussion in Sport Australia website. 

The Sport Concussion Assessment Tool (‘SCAT5’) can assist with this process.

Competition Settings

How Concussion Is Handled During A Bout

Section 23 of the Professional Boxing and Combat Sports Act 1985 ensures that Rules are made in  the interests of contestant safety.  The Rules address concussion diagnosis and management for  professional boxing and combat sports in Victoria, including:  

  • Giving the ringside physician the power to stop the contest or provide medical aid to  an injured contestant if they believe that:  
  • A contestant has an impaired ability to defend themselves 
  • There is a risk of injury to a contestant’s health if they continue 
  • It is in the interests of the safety or welfare of a contestant 
  • Giving the referee the power to stop a contest or request the ringside physician  examine a contestant if:  
  • A contestant has an impaired ability to defend themselves  
  • There is a risk of serious injury to a contestant’s health if the contest were to  continue 
  • It is in the interests of the safety or welfare of a contestant.  
  • Giving the referee the power to seek a medical examination if a contestant:  o is subject to heavy physical force 
  • Receives many heavy blows to the head 
  • Appears to be suffering from signs and symptoms consistent with a  
  • Concussion.   
  • Giving the Board or the trainer of a contestant the power to request the medical  practitioner examines the contestant if they suspect a concussion. 

Diagnosis and Management

A medical practitioner should diagnose a concussion

The ringside doctor does this in the combat  sport competition setting and their finding is final.  

Concussed contestants must:

not drink alcohol while symptoms persist, particularly not after a contest

get as much rest as possible and avoid demanding activities or those that need a lot of  thinking or concentration while symptoms persist  

not return to sparring until granted medical clearance 

Immediately attend a hospital emergency department if experiencing the following symptoms:

Repeated Vomiting

Increasing and persisting headaches

Loss of  consciousness

Inability to stay awake during time when usually awake

Confusion

Restlessness

Agitation

Convulsions

Seizures

Difficulty walking

Difficulty balancing

Weakness or numbness

Blurring or difficulty with vision

Slurred Speech

Mental Health and Concussion

There is a potential link between mental illness and concussion.  Contestants with a history of mental illness should discuss this with a doctor. Where there is a history of mental illness, a more cautious assessment and a more conservative management approach should be taken.

There are a number of organisations with information on mental llness and where to go for help.

  • Lifeline provides a 24 hour, 365 days per year crisis support and suicide prevention  service. It is free and provides immediate support for those in need.  
  • Headspace is a national youth mental health support service providing mental health  assistance to those aged 12–25. 
  • Beyond Blue is an organization aimed at improving community mental health education  and awareness through several programs.  

Potential Complications

These include:

  • Severe brain swelling. 
  • Increased risk of further concussions or other musculoskeletal injury 
  • Prolonged symptoms. 
  • Psychological problems including symptoms of depression or anxiety 
  • Long term damage to brain function

 

There is an increased risk of complications from a concussion if a contestant returns to training or  competition before recovering completely. A repeat concussion that occurs before the brain has  healed can be dangerous. It may also slow recovery and increase the chance of long-term problems.  It is essential to recognise a possible concussion and seek medical assessment and treatment while  refraining from training and competition until recovery is complete.  

Long-Term Consequences

There are a number of potential long-term consequences of concussion, including Chronic Traumatic  Encephalopathy (CTE) which is a type of degenerative neurological disease.  


The best way to safeguard the immediate and long term health of contestants is to:

Remove contestants suspected of having concussion 

Treat each case of concussion carefully  

Adopt a conservative approach to return to fight.  

Further Resources

Clearinghouse for Sport

Clearinghouse for Sport hosts a wide range of resources on sport concussions and head trauma  from across Australia and the globe.  This site aims to assist those working or linked to sport to  understand and maintain awareness of relevant policies, guidelines, insights and emerging research in  this area.  

The Concussion in Sport Australia Initiative

The Concussion in Sport Australia initiative brings together the most contemporary evidence-based  information on concussion for athletes, parents, teachers, coaches and medical practitioners. It  provides a valuable and trusted resource for the management of sports-related concussion for all  Australians, regardless of the sport, location or level of participation. It is a joint initiative of the  Australian Institute of Sport, the Australian Medical Association, the Australasian College of Sport and  Exercise Physicians, and Sport Medicine Australia.  

For the Concussion in Sport Australia Position Statement visit:  

Concussion Sport 

For athletes visit: 

Concussion Sport

For coaches, trainers and support staff visit:  

Concussion Sport

For medical practitioners visit: 

Concussion Sport 

The ‘Consensus Statement on Concussion in Sport’

Was devised to help develop an  understanding of sport-related concussion (SRC) using an expert consensus-based approach. The  aim of the Consensus Statement is to assist those involved in athlete care to manage concussion  safely whether at a recreational, elite or professional level. The authors acknowledge that the science  of SRC is evolving and therefore individual management and return-to-play decisions must be made  by a medical physician.  

An updated statement in line with the 6th International Consensus Conference on Concussion in Sport, 27-28 October 2022 will provide an important opportunity for world experts and researchers in  concussion in sport to present new evidence and reach agreement on the definition, management,  treatment and return to sport protocols for athletes at the recreational, elite or professional level.    

Sports Medicine Australia’s Concussion in Sport Policy provides important information about how to recognise and manage .

Concussion Video Resources

Below are additional concussion education videos to help you better understand this important topic. For further explanation and detailed information on each video, please visit the Victorian Government’s Combat Sports page at the link below. 

Click here to see more >>>

Brain Trauma Defined and Substance Impact

Brain trauma refers to any injury to the brain, ranging from mild concussions to severe traumatic brain injuries (TBI). When substances like drugs and alcohol are introduced into the system, they disrupt brain function and significantly increase the risk of sustaining and worsening brain trauma. Here’s a detailed look at how drugs and alcohol affect the brain and how these effects relate to brain injuries.

How Drugs and Alcohol effect the Brain

Potential Effects

  • Disruption of Normal Brain Function
    Drugs and alcohol interfere with the brain’s natural communication pathways, impairing the transmission of important signals. This leads to problems with:

    • Memory: Difficulty retaining information or recalling past events.
    • Decision-Making: Poor choices due to impaired judgment.
    • Coordination and Balance: Loss of motor control, increasing the risk of falls and accidents.

    Relation to Brain Trauma: Impaired coordination and decision-making increase the likelihood of injuries, including head trauma. In sports like boxing or other contact sports, this makes fighters more susceptible to concussions and other brain injuries.

  • Slower Recovery from Brain Injury
    The brain has an incredible ability to repair itself, a process known as neuroplasticity. However, substance use limits the brain’s capacity to heal, leading to:

    • Reduced Neuroplasticity: The brain’s natural ability to adapt and heal is slowed down.
    • Longer Recovery Time: Injuries like concussions take longer to heal, and the brain may never fully recover.

    Relation to Brain Trauma: After sustaining a brain injury, individuals who use drugs or alcohol are at a higher risk of incomplete recovery. Their brain is less resilient, making the damage more lasting.

  • Increased Brain Inflammation
    Chronic substance use often leads to inflammation in the brain, which:

    • Increases Pressure on Brain Tissue: Swelling can intensify the effects of a brain injury.
    • Exacerbates Existing Injuries: A brain already suffering from trauma will be more severely impacted by this inflammation.

    Relation to Brain Trauma: Post-injury swelling can lead to complications such as prolonged symptoms, cognitive decline, or permanent damage, all of which are worsened by substance use.

  • Worsening Cognitive Deficits
    Long-term drug or alcohol use affects key cognitive functions, such as:

    • Attention: Difficulty focusing and concentrating.
    • Problem-Solving: Struggles with logic and reasoning.
    • Memory: Short- and long-term memory impairments.

    Relation to Brain Trauma: Brain injuries also target these same cognitive functions, meaning individuals with a history of substance use will experience more severe and lasting deficits following an injury. For athletes and officials, this can impact their ability to make quick and accurate decisions during high-pressure situations.

  • Neurotoxicity
    Drugs and alcohol can directly kill brain cells, a process known as neurotoxicity. This leads to:

    • Loss of Neurons: Permanent reduction in brain cell count, which weakens brain function.
    • Increased Vulnerability: A weakened brain is more susceptible to the impacts of trauma.

    Relation to Brain Trauma: When the brain is already compromised due to neurotoxic effects, even mild trauma can have exaggerated consequences, leading to more severe symptoms and longer-lasting injuries.

  • Delayed Response Times
    Reaction time is crucial in preventing injuries, especially in sports or high-risk environments. Drugs and alcohol:

    • Slow Reaction Times: Reduce the brain’s ability to process and respond to stimuli.
    • Impair Judgment: Lead to poor decision-making and riskier behavior.

    Relation to Brain Trauma: Delayed responses increase the risk of accidents and injuries. In contact sports, this can result in fighters failing to protect themselves adequately, leading to more head injuries.

  • Increased Risk of Repeat Injuries
    Substance use not only impairs immediate functioning but also increases the likelihood of recurring injuries:

    • Impaired Coordination: More prone to falls or accidents, especially in dangerous environments.
    • Poor Judgment: More likely to make risky choices that result in further injury.

    Relation to Brain Trauma: After a brain injury, proper recovery is essential to prevent re-injury. Drug or alcohol use disrupts this process, leading to repeated trauma that compounds the damage.

  • Permanent Brain Damage
    Long-term use of drugs or alcohol causes permanent changes in the brain, such as:

    • Brain Shrinkage: Loss of brain volume, particularly in areas related to memory and decision-making.
    • White Matter Damage: White matter is crucial for communication between different brain regions, and its damage can lead to cognitive decline.

    Relation to Brain Trauma: Brain injuries cause structural damage, and when combined with substance-induced shrinkage or white matter damage, it can result in chronic issues like memory loss, difficulty thinking clearly, and susceptibility to further injuries.
